entry.title: Combined summary - (space) efficient reusable addr via weil pairing IBE (Re: Bait for reusable addresses)
entry.summary: Several discussions were held among experts in the blockchain industry to find different approaches to encrypting transactions and making them searchable by specific parties. Two approaches were discussed, with the first approach using identity keys, epoch-pubkeys, ephemeral privkeys/pubkeys, shared secrets, encryption keys, and bloom bait to create a searchable encryption of a keyword or per-block/epoch private key. The second approach involves PEKS (Public Key Encryption with Keyword Search), which limits the discoverability of transactions to the nodes that your SPV client is actually communicating with for specific blocks/epochs.Adam Back proposed a proof-of-concept solution for better space efficiency and linkability defense reusable addresses using an IBE scheme as a building block. He discussed this concept with several people, including Greg Maxwell, Peter Todd, Jeremy Spillman, Mike Hearn, and Bytecoin. They also talked about a simplified ECC-based version to solve the problem of Alice wanting to pay Bob, who is bandwidth constrained and frequently offline, while Ivan has a full node but can't be trusted, and Eve is trying to piece together everyone's financial details.In an email exchange between Adam Back, Peter Todd, and Jeremy Spilman, the group discussed the implementation of an Identity-Based Encryption (IBE) scheme for filtering transactions. The IBE scheme involves 'filter' and 'recovery' pubkeys to encrypt a short string of zeros, which is then placed in transactions for later third-party decryption. This allows for a searchable encryption of a keyword or per-block/epoch private key.Additionally, alternative methods such as one-use, stealth, or IBE addresses are suggested depending on the circumstances. Adam Back also posted about his idea of a proof for the existence of a space-efficient way to do better than bloom filters/prefix/bloom-bait, using novel application of IBE based on weil-pairing. This allows the recipient to send a delegation private key specific to the block being queried, so the node servicing the query has no ability to correlate with queries in other blocks from the same user.In conclusion, these discussions among experts highlight various methods and approaches to increase privacy and security in blockchain transactions. These concepts include identity keys, epoch-pubkeys, ephemeral privkeys/pubkeys, shared secrets, encryption keys, bloom bait, PEKS, IBE schemes, and one-use, stealth, or IBE addresses. The proposals put forth provide an in-depth analysis of different approaches to securely and efficiently delegating block searching and encrypting transactions for greater privacy in a blockchain network.
